Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as d763db35ef85da1cabae911d704a219175347621
How about "Prevent deletion if it is associated with HWIsolation"?

hardware isolation - Lets use openbmc terms instead of guard.

and please include the purpose ("why") or the problem statement for this change in the generic description.
Please avoid internal planning details in the open source project.

Production code and basic testing is done. 
Unit test cases, clang based code formatting will be addressed in the future patch.
I think you could write a unit test for this using something similar to the area here: https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/test/openpower-pels/pel_manager_test.cpp#L171
I would suggest defining arguments for these DBus parameters as well, as it would provide more flexibility to the caller.
You could use `DBusPath` for associatedPath as well since it is path value.

You can simply use the entry variable by appending `/isolated_hw_entry` to it since the variable isn't being reused.

For example,
```
auto entry += "/isolated_hw_entry";
```
Just a suggestion: You could directly pass interfaces in the below call to avoid additional variable.

we can hold up to 3000 PELs, so when deleting all won't this make 3000 D-Bus calls?  
That sounds horribly slow for something that should be fast.  Or, to prove it isn't, can you create 3000 PELs and then get timings of doing a delete all with and without this code?

 I was thinking it would do something like maintain a cache of the hwIsolation's D-Bus model by watching signals so it wouldn't have to make any calls at all.

I think caching with DBus signals would be more complex, so I would prefer to consider that option last.

What I'm thinking is, can we use `GetAssociatedSubTreePaths` to retrieve a list of entry paths associated with HWIsolation? If yes, then we could define a callback or refactor getLogIDWithHwIsolation to obtain a list of prohibited entries and use it while attempting to call erase() to delete each PEL.

So just the one call on an eraseAll?  Yea that sounds good, assuming log_manager can be modified in a way that isn't just IBM specific and doesn't affect others (though I guess we could use compile flags if we had to)

The API proposer did not accept the suggestion and requested that it be tracked separately. As a result, we will be using the getLogIDWithHwIsolation API, which calls five DBus APIs once during the DeleteAll operation.
Please add trace with necessary data so that it will help debuggability.
Not required, it seems code changed a bit.

How did you determine that it will be `unsigned int`? its `uint32_t` since your are return the greatest entry id, right?

I would recommend using `auto`.

You could use `std::ranges::max_element`.

For example,
```
auto maxEntryIdIt = std::ranges::max_element(entries, [](const auto& a, const auto& b) { return a.first < b.first; });
```
Unit test cases will be addressed in the future patch.
Unit test cases will be addressed in the future patch.
how about 'LogIDs' everywhere you have this, since it's a vector?
nit: vars should be lower case, so hwIsolation...
the guidelines still want braces around single line if statements.  Alternatively, you could also do:  return !paths.empty()
I don't see the code checking the Resolved property?  is it supposed to, or can the comment just be removed.

I think I'd feel better if you kept the original code in the normal path like:

if (Extensions::getLogIDWithHwIsolationFunctions().empty())
   do original eraseAll code
else
   this new stuff
   
   
Since we're the only users of this, I feel like it would have the ability to impact others less.
emplace_back is typically used for constructing a new element in place within the container, which wouldn't happen here.  Won't hurt anything though
I believe adding `associatedPath`, `subtree`, and `interfaces` to the trace will assist in debugging issues, as these values are not constant.
Suggestion: You can use `DBusPath`, and the same applies to other places.
I think this may be a bit more clear with a 'get' on front.  This goes for manager's implementation too.
The function doesn't return anything, hence left 'out', following older pattern
IMO...Its filling the value in the given reference argument so it need to be `out`.
nit: The guidelines ask for  { } even for 1 liners here.

could you just skip the temporary and do:
entryId = std::ranges...

Not that it matters that much since we don't use the multiple plugins, but if you just had the extension functions up above push_back a unique number and not do a clear you'd be able to test that it called both of them.
Its not readable, you are calling out the DIMM, not the proc.
could you also just do calloutFile.data() here?

I believe this test case addresses three distinct scenarios:

1. Not associated with HWIsolation.
2. No PEL entries.
3. Deletion is not prohibited.

Ideally, each of these should be separate test cases instead of combining them into one. However, I understand that phosphor-logging uses this style in some instances, so it's acceptable. Those cases are still readable because they are clearly scoped with curly braces to distinguish the different test scenarios. Please follow that approach if you prefer to cover multiple scenarios in a single test case.
Could be something meaningful. PGOOD is not relevant here. The same applies to below TC.
Not readable. Not matching with FRU type. The same applies to below TC.
Suggestion: I think we could have test case for the scenario "Guard flag is false".
Move this after PEL create. LN1378. The same applies to below TC.

Suggestion: It might need some adjustment, and the main focus for debugging should be the interfaces, as they are key to retrieving the associated object path.

```
std::string ifaces(std::ranges::fold_left_first(interfaces,
                   [](std::string ifaces, const std::string& iface) { return ifaces + ", " + iface; }));
lg2::error("Failed getting associated paths: {ERROR}. "
           "AssociatedPath: {ASSOIC_PATH} Subtree: {SUBTREE} "
           "Interfaces: {IFACES}", 
           "ERROR", e, "ASSOIC_PATH", associatedPath, "SUBTREE", subtree,
           "IFACES", ifaces);
```

Or you could wait for Matt's input. I believe he's hesitant to add more details to the trace, especially if it involves hard-coded values, to maintain code readability.

(Noticed somewhere his comment on the similar line)

Not a huge deal, since there's not a lot of users of this utility function we can figure out what was passed in, but Ramesh's example is a bit more complete, so we could go with that.

Also I just learned about fold_left_first!

> This goes for manager's implementation too.

I think you missed to update manager function name

I don't think it's necessary, as the Guarded field isn't supported in the message registry JSON, and including it might cause confusion when reviewing the `TestPELDeleteWithoutHWIsolation` test case name.
